text:
it appears when firefox is started with the `--marionette` argument that alerts do not happen  (seen in firefox 85 and 87 nightly (2021-02-19) 64bit windows and 85 on linux)


steps to reproduce

* download jenkins from https://get.jenkins.io/war-stable/2.263.4/jenkins.war 
* install jdk 8 https://adoptopenjdk.net/index.html
* run jenkins (`jenkins_home=tmpfolder; java -djenkins.install.runsetupwizard=false -jar jenkins.war --httplistenaddress=127.0.0.1`


start a firefox normally 
* navigate to http://localhost:8080/
* click "new view" in the left hand bar
* enter some random alpha-numeric characters for the `view name`
* select "list view" option
* click ok
* enter some random text in the "description field"
* click "new item" in the left hand bar

observe a alert saying "this page is asking you to confirm that you want to leave - data you have entered may not be saved."

close firefox.

start firefox as if geckodriver had started it e.g.
* `firefox.exe "--marionette" "-foreground" "-no-remote" "-profile" "c:\\users\\jnord\\appdata\\local\\temp\\rust_mozprofilen6vbxm"`
* navigate to http://localhost:8080/
* click "new view" in the left hand bar
* enter some random alpha-numeric characters for the `view name`
* select "list view" option
* click ok
* enter some random text in the "description field"
* click "new item" in the left hand bar

observe the lack of any alert

this was extracted from observing the failure of https://github.com/jenkinsci/acceptance-test-harness/blob/master/src/test/java/core/formvalidationtest.java failing to show any alert window and the waitfor(alert) timing out.
user_behviou:
Based on the provided text, I would rate it as:

* Content: Good (the bug report provides a clear description of the issue, including the steps to reproduce)
* Grammar: Best (the text is well-written and easy to understand)

The report includes all 4 essential items:

1. Steps to Reproduce (S2R): Detailed steps to replicate the issue.
2. Expected Result (ER): What you expected to happen.
3. Actual Result (AR): What actually happened.
4. Additional Information: Include relevant details such as software version, build number, environment, etc.

The only thing missing is code or logs, but this is not a requirement for a bug report.
NEW_llama_output:
Here's a rewritten version of the bug report in a natural, conversational tone:

"So I'm testing Firefox with the `--marionette` argument, and what I've noticed is that alerts just don't seem to work when you start it up this way. Specifically, I've tried reproducing this issue on both Windows (Firefox 85 and 87 nightlies) and Linux (just Firefox 85), and consistently, no alert pops up. Now, I know this might sound weird, but stick with me - what's happening is that if you start a Jenkins server first, and then launch Firefox normally, you'll see the expected behavior: when you try to leave a page without saving your changes, an alert will pop up asking you to confirm whether you really want to bail. But here's the thing: if you restart Firefox with the `--marionette` flag (like this: `firefox.exe "--marionette" "-foreground" "-no-remote" "-profile" "c:\\users\\jnord\\appdata\\local\\temp\\rust_mozprofilen6vbxm"`), and then try to reproduce that same behavior - navigating to Jenkins, clicking around, entering some dummy text... nothing. No alert shows up. I was trying to debug this issue by running a test script (https://github.com/jenkinsci/acceptance-test-harness/blob/master/src/test/java/core/formvalidationtest.java), and what it kept timing out on was the `waitFor(alert)` part - which makes sense, given that no alert is actually being shown. So yeah, I'm basically reporting that Firefox doesn't show alerts when you start it up with `--marionette`."

created attachment 9389352
screen recording 2024-03-05 at 12.56.56.mov

**found in**
* beta 124.0b7 (2024-03-04)

**affected versions**
* nightly 125.0a1 (2024-03-04)
* beta 124.0b7
* release 123

**tested platforms**
* affected platforms: all

**steps to reproduce**
1. open any pdf which has a text field in firefox (eg: http://foersom.com/net/howto/data/oopdfformexample.pdf).
2. add text in any one of the fields.
3. enable the highlight tool.
4. free highlight the added text.
5. save the pdf and reopen it in firefox.
6. click inside the highlighted field and try to add some text.

**expected result**
* the text can be added successfully, without any issue.

**actual result**
* highlighting the field will add a layer which won't let the user to click behind it.  

**regression range**
* not a regression.

**additional notes**
* if the field is entirely highlighted, saved and then reopened that will make impossible for the user to add text to that field.
user_behviou:
Based on the provided bug report, I would rate it as:

**Good**

The report meets the following criteria:

1. Steps to Reproduce (S2R): Detailed steps to replicate the issue.
2. Expected Result (ER): What you expected to happen.
3. Actual Result (AR): What actually happened.
4. Additional Information: Include relevant details such as software version, build number, environment, etc.

The report does not contain code or logs, which is in line with your expectations.
NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report:

"I ran into this weird issue while testing some PDFs in Firefox. It happened with any version from beta 124.0b7 (which was on March 4) all the way back to release 123. So, here's what I did: I opened a random PDF that had text fields (like this one [http://foersom.com/net/howto/data/oopdfformexample.pdf]), added some text to one of those fields, and then enabled the highlight tool. No big deal so far, right? But then things got weird - when I went ahead and free highlighted the text, saved the PDF, and reopened it in Firefox, trying to add more text to that same field became impossible because a layer was created (I recorded this whole process as a screen recording, just in case: attachment 9389352). Honestly, I expected everything to work smoothly - I mean, who doesn't want to be able to add text to highlighted fields? But instead, it's like the highlight tool creates some kind of barrier that makes clicking behind it impossible. And if I'm totally honest, things get even worse if I completely highlight a field, save it, and then reopen it: at that point, adding any new text is basically out of the question."

**steps to reproduce:**
1. have the "swipe between page" mouse gesture enabled for your magic mouse (one finger)
2. go to any page where the over scrolling effect is visible enough (make sure you have only 1 site opened in that tab - no tab history)
3. perform multiple swipe down gestures
4. while the above step is in progress, perform a fast-short right or left gesture (for swipe between pages - one finger for magic mouse, 2 fingers for trackpad)

**expected results:**
the overscroll effect should finish the animation (if there is no tab history available)

**actual result:**
the rubberbanding animation is stuck and is not reset until scrolling again on that site.
reproducible with magic mouse and trackpad gestures for "swipe between pages".

please see attached recordings for reference: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1omhx3kzl1dtaaj4ij0usjxbianlvepwk/view?usp=sharing

Here's the rewritten bug report:

So, I've been noticing this weird issue with Firefox and my Magic Mouse on a Mac (running 10.15). When I have the swipe gesture enabled for between pages and over-scrolling is turned on, things get wonky. Here's what happens: if I perform multiple swipe down gestures to scroll through a webpage, then try to quickly swipe right or left with one finger (or two fingers on my trackpad) to switch between tabs while the animation is still running, the rubberbanding effect just gets stuck and refuses to reset until I start scrolling again. This happens with both my Magic Mouse and trackpad, so it's not a hardware-specific issue. I've attached some recordings to demonstrate the problem if you want to take a look (link: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1omhx3kzl1dtaaj4ij0usjxbianlvepwk/view?usp=sharing). Interestingly, this doesn't happen when using Safari, so it's specific to Firefox.

text:
created attachment 9225367
screenshot 2021-06-05 115915.png

user agent: mozilla/5.0 (windows nt 10.0; win64; x64; rv:89.0) gecko/20100101 firefox/89.0

steps to reproduce:

firefox 89 is opened with two tabs.
1 - i click on the 'save to pocket' icon when i'm on the first tab.
2 - then i switch to the second tab.
3 - finally i switch back to the first tab.


actual results:

1 - the pocket icon turns red, indicating that the tab is saved.
2 - the pocket icon turns red too, incorrectly indicating that the tab is saved
3 - the pocket icon has been reset to black, incorrectly indicating that the tab is not saved


expected results:

1 - ok, this is the correct behavior
2 - pocket icon should stay dark when i move to another tab that has not been saved.
3 - when going back to a saved tab, the pocket icon should reflect the saved status (this last one is more an enhancement, as i think we had this behavior before firefox 89)
basically the pocket icon should always reflect the status of the tab (saved or not in pocket)
user_behviou: good
NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report:

"I was messing around with Firefox 89 and noticed some weirdness with the 'Save to Pocket' feature. So, I opened two tabs and started testing. First, I clicked the 'Save to Pocket' icon on the first tab - no big deal, it turned red as expected. Then, I switched to the second tab and did nothing. Finally, I went back to the first tab... and that's when things got wonky. The pocket icon not only stayed red (like it should), but also changed color on the second tab! I mean, I hadn't even tried to save that one yet. To top it off, when I went back to the original saved tab, the icon was suddenly black again, like nothing had ever been saved in the first place. It looks like the pocket icon is getting out of sync with the actual state of the tabs - especially when switching between them. My expectation would be that the icon stays dark on an unsaved tab and reflects the saved status (or not) on a saved one. Maybe this behavior changed with Firefox 89, but I think it's worth looking into."

text:
user agent: mozilla/5.0 (windows nt 10.0; win64; x64; rv:90.0) gecko/20100101 firefox/90.0

steps to reproduce:

- i noticed this on windows 10, nightly 90.0a1, build 20210525093431, with proton settings enabled. i went ahead and made a brand new, empty profile with the profile manager to test it. the bug is always present, seems to just be an oversight

str:
- click & hold on the new tab button
- opens a context menu, `.new-tab-popup`
- click "no container", it opens a new tab with context id 0
- now right click the new tab button
- opens a similar context menu, `#new-tab-button-popup`
- click "no container"


actual results:

- it does nothing
- looking at the dom, the menus look identical. in both cases the menuitems for the actual containers have `command` attributes that invoke [opennewusercontexttab](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/browser/base/content/browser.js#4857), which gets the context id from an attribute on the click event target, the menuitem.
- but in both popups, the "no container" menuitem has no command attribute, nor does it have any other event listeners.


expected results:

so why the different behavior — i think this is because the click & hold popup is a child of the new tab button, whereas the right-click popup is off on its own in `#mainpopupset`.

so when you click the "no container" item in the click & hold popup, the event is bubbling up to the new tab button, which has event listeners like `command="cmd_newnavigatortab"` and `oncommand="browseropentab(event);"`.

when you click the same item in the right-click popup, nothing opens because there isn't any command event listener targeting it or its parent.

you can see that adding `command="cmd_newnavigatortab"` or `command="browser:newusercontexttab"` to the "no container" item in the right-click menu fixes the issue. the command attribute can also just be added to the right-click menupopup itself.

so i'm pretty sure the issue is purely that there aren't any event listeners for the "no container" items, and i guess this was just overlooked because it's accidentally working correctly in the click & hold menu, due to the event bubbling up to an element that just so happens to have an almost identical purpose/behavior.

so i think my suggestion is to add the command attribute to the menuitem [when it's being created](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/browser/base/content/utilityoverlay.js#780).
user_behviou:
Here's my assessment:

* Content: GOOD (The report provides relevant information about the issue, including steps to reproduce, expected results, actual results, and additional context.)
* Grammar: BEST (The writing is clear and concise, with no grammatical errors or awkward phrasing.)

* Expected Result (ER): GOOD (The ER section clearly explains what the reporter expected to happen and how they think the issue arose.)
* Actual Result (AR): GOOD (The AR section provides clear information about what actually happened when the reporter performed the actions.)

Overall, this is a good bug report. It's well-written, easy to follow, and provides all the necessary information for someone to understand and reproduce the issue.
NEW_llama_output:
Here's a rewritten version of the bug report in a natural, conversational tone:

"I noticed this weird issue on my Windows 10 machine running Firefox Nightly 90.0a1 (build 20210525093431) with Proton settings enabled. I created a brand new profile just to test it out and the problem is always there - seems like an oversight.

So, here's what happens: if you click and hold on the new tab button, a context menu pops up (.new-tab-popup) and if you click "No Container", it opens a new tab with context ID 0. But then, when you right-click the new tab button (which opens another context menu, #new-tab-button-popup), clicking "No Container" does nothing. I checked the DOM and the menus look identical - both have those menu items for actual containers that invoke openNewUserContextTab, which gets the context ID from an attribute on the click event target. The thing is, in both popups, the "No Container" menu item has no command attribute or any other event listeners.

I think this is because the click and hold popup is a child of the new tab button, whereas the right-click popup is its own thing in #mainpopupset. When you click "No Container" in the click and hold popup, the event bubbles up to the new tab button, which has those event listeners like command="cmd_newnavigatortab" and oncommand="browseropentab(event);". But when you do the same thing in the right-click popup, nothing opens because there's no command event listener targeting it or its parent.

What I think is that we just need to add some event listeners for the "No Container" items. Adding command="cmd_newnavigatortab" or command="browser:newusercontexttab" to the right-click menu fixes the issue, and you can also just add it to the menupopup itself. So, my suggestion is to just add that attribute when the menu item is being created (utilityoverlay.js#780)."

Here's what's happening: when I print a webpage (like Wikipedia) and then press the 'print' button, a notification pops up from the DLP agent saying it's reviewing some data. If I then quickly resize the browser window during this transition to the 'you're not permitted...' blocked dialog, Firefox just freezes and becomes unresponsive - even taking over my entire desktop! It doesn't matter what OS I'm on (tested on Windows 10/11), but it only happens when resizing during that specific print preview flow. If I close Firefox from Task Manager, everything goes back to normal. Weirdly, this issue seems linked to bug 1899714, but I can't confirm for sure since the same bug is involved. Anyways, I've attached a video showing the whole thing in action - take a look and let me know what's going on!"

"I encountered this weird issue when I tried out `requestfullscreen`. So, if you run an unresponsive script that blocks the main thread or freezes the page, and then try to navigate to another website at the same time - get this - the browser will actually go into fullscreen mode on the new website without showing that typical "going into fullscreen" toast notification! 3. ensure that the “set as default” infobar is displayed.

NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report:

I'm experiencing a weird issue with Firefox Beta 109.0b1 (build id: 20221212143511) on Windows 10 x64, macOS 11.7.1, and Ubuntu 22.04 x64. To reproduce it, you need to have the latest beta version installed, along with a Firefox profile that's between 6 weeks and 3 months old (just create one if yours is newer!). Also, make sure your browser isn't set as default, and you've got "nimbus.debug" set to true in about:config. Additionally, uncheck the "always check if firefox is your default browser" option from the about:preferences page.

This issue is also reproducible in treatment B of the experiment, and the second message of the pdf callout points to the info bar as well. I've attached a screenshot of the issue for reference.

user_behviou: Good
NEW_llama_output:
So, I'm getting an error when trying to print the value of a variable called `baseloc` in a program. The issue is that `baseloc` hasn't been initialized yet, so it's not actually a thing we can access or print. This causes the whole discovery process to fail if there's a text record involved (it's part of a calendar discovery thing). 

Here's what I found when I dug into the code - in this file `modules/caldavprovider.jsm`, around line 186, there's some logic that tries to create an object called `baseloc` from a URL. But it looks like `baseloc` is being used before it's actually been defined. It's trying to print its value with the line `cal.log(`[caldavprovider] trying ${baseloc.spec} from srv and txt response`)`, but `baseloc` isn't yet set up, so that fails.

affected versions:
- nightly (117.0a1/20230712214907)
- beta (116.0b4/20230711183052)

description:
when a user grants/revokes access to an add-on to restricted sites via the controls on the add-on detail page, a pref is created in about:config `extensions.quarantineignoredbyuser.extension_id` which is set to either true or false.
if the add-on is uninstalled, the pref will remain listed in about:config.

steps to reproduce:
1. install a non-recommended add-on, for example https://addons.mozilla.org/en-us/firefox/addon/honey/
2. access the add-on detail page in about:addons and from the “run on sites with restrictions” section allow the add-on access to restricted sites by selecting “allow”
3. access about:config and check to see that the pref - “extensions.quarantineignoredbyuser.jid1-93cwpmrbvpjrqa@jetpack” – has been created
4. uninstall the add-on
5. return to about:config and check for the presence of the above pref
6. notice the pref has not been cleared upon removing the add-on

actual:
the `extensions.quarantineignoredbyuser.extension_id` pref persists in about:config after uninstalling the add-on.

expected:
clear the `extensions.quarantineignoredbyuser.extension_id` pref upon add-on removal.
user_behviou: "good"
NEW_llama_output:
Here's a rewritten version of the bug report in a natural, conversational tone:

"So, I noticed this weird thing happening when I installed an add-on and then uninstalled it later. When you allow an add-on to access restricted sites on its detail page in about:addons, Firefox creates a preference in about:config called `extensions.quarantineignoredbyuser.extension_id` that's set to either true or false, depending on whether you granted or revoked access. The thing is, when you uninstall the add-on later, this pref doesn't get cleared out of about:config - it just sticks around. It happens with non-recommended add-ons like Honey, which I used as an example. To reproduce this bug, you can follow these steps: install a non-recommended add-on, access its detail page and allow it to access restricted sites, check that the pref has been created in about:config, uninstall the add-on, and then come back to about:config to see that the pref is still there. What's supposed to happen is that when you remove an add-on, this preference should get cleared out - but right now, it doesn't."

created attachment 9405836
download all languages.mp4

### steps to reproduce
1. make sure to enable the translations feature on fenix nightly/beta.
2. go to three-dot menu - settings - translations - download languages.
3. tap on the "all languages" and wait for the download to finish, while observing.

### expected behavior
after tapping the download icon, the "all languages" option is not displayed anymore 
all the download icons near the languages are replaced by the loading icon.
as soon as the languages are downloaded, the loading icon is replaced by the delete icon.
the "delete all languages" option is displayed as soon as at least one of the languages is downloaded.

### actual behavior
some of the languages remain in the loading state for a while. 
after a while, the loading icons are being replaced by the download icons.

### device information
* firefox version: nightly 128.0a1
* android device: google pixel 6 (android 14)

### any additional information?
* this is not 100% reproducible; 
* i mostly reproduce this after i've downloaded all the languages, deleted them all, and redownloaded them.
user_behviou:
I'd rate this bug report as:

**Good**

Reason: The report includes 4 essential components:

1. Steps to Reproduce (S2R): Detailed steps to replicate the issue.
2. Expected Result (ER): Clear description of what was expected to happen.
3. Actual Result (AR): Description of what actually happened.
4. Additional Information: Relevant details about the device and environment.

The report is well-structured, easy to follow, and provides sufficient context for debugging.
NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report:

So, I noticed a weird issue with the translations feature on Fenix Nightly/Beta - specifically when downloading all languages. Here's what happens: first, you gotta enable the translations feature in settings, then go to three-dot menu > settings > translations > download languages. When you tap "All Languages" and wait for it to finish downloading, a few things happen that don't quite make sense. Initially, all the download icons next to each language disappear and are replaced with loading icons. But once some of the languages are actually downloaded, the loading icons turn into delete icons, and you get the option to "Delete All Languages". That's not what I'm complaining about - it's what happens after that. Sometimes, some of the languages just stay stuck in the loading state for a bit before finally showing the download icon again. And then, out of nowhere, the delete icon shows up, even if you haven't actually deleted any languages yet! It seems like this issue is linked to downloading all languages, deleting them, and then redownloading them - not super reproducible, but it happens often enough that I thought I'd report it.

"I'm reporting an issue with Firefox Nightly 93.0a1 (build id: 20210820095755) on both Windows 10 x64 and Ubuntu 20.04 x64. To reproduce this problem, you'll need to have a Firefox profile set up with the "messaging-system.rsexperimentloader.collection_id" pref set to "nimbus-preview" in the about:config page. Instead, it just vanished. By the way, this issue doesn't happen on Mac OS - there, the infobar shows up only after a login action from the OS windows. I've attached a screen recording of the whole thing, so you can see what happened."

text:
created attachment 9437090
rendertest.html

**user agent**: mozilla/5.0 (windows nt 10.0; win64; x64; rv:132.0) gecko/20100101 firefox/132.0

**steps to reproduce:**
check out the source of the attached file demo. or follow these instructions:
create a group of dom elements inside a stage that is longer than its container. the overflow is hidden.
each element is positioned next to another, at a small distance.
add pointer event listeners with attached handlers that read the user's dragging actions over the stage surface.
apply the pointer dragging delta value on the x translation value of each element from the group, using a for-loop that adjusts each x coordinate by this delta.

**expected result:**
all the dom elements from this stage should move in lockstep on a dragging action, without any delays, since all of them have exactly the same kind of translations and transition applied at once, collectively.

**actual result:**
dom elements that are outside the viewport of the stage container and which come into view from the hidden overflow area show a graphical delay while rendering the translation on which the same transition string is applied.
you can see this by running the demo i attached in the latest firefox (132) and comparing that to the latest chrome (131). or you could try load the video from the link below -- the firefox test is on the top side, the chrome test is on the bottom side.

**video demo:**
http://163.172.222.229/temp/v.mp4
(file will be taken down after this case gets resolved)

don't know how to use the regression tool and don't have time to invest in this, but i did something to help you out. i downloaded past versions of firefox and tested to see which was the last version in which rendering was normal for this case. that was **123.0**. the rendering problem can be seen already in version **124.0**, so that will narrow it down for you to just a few intermediary versions.

i imagine it's a similar cause as the last time i reported a rendering bug. you're doing some optimisation somewhere: elements are queued for graphical updates but those in the hidden overflow area get their update on the next tick, to improve performance. but this makes elements in scenarios like this one behave in a way that breaks the logic of "same rules applied to similar elements should behave in the same way". i think browser optimisations should not break how elements should behave according to web standards.

i hope this can get resolved in less than a month. thanks.
user_behviou:
**good**

However, it does not include code or logs, which is okay according to your request.
NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report:

I've attached a file called rendertest.html that shows an issue with Firefox (specifically version 132.0) - it's really annoying and I'm hoping someone can help me fix it! 

So, here's what's going on: when you have a bunch of elements inside a container stage, where the overflow is hidden, and each element is positioned next to another at a small distance, if you add pointer event listeners that apply dragging actions over the stage surface, all the elements should move in sync. And they do - except for those outside the viewport that come into view from the hidden overflow area. 

In Firefox 132.0, there's this weird graphical delay when these elements come into view, like the rendering of their translation is being delayed or something. It's really noticeable if you compare it to the same test in Chrome (version 131). I've even made a video demo that shows this issue - it's at http://163.172.222.229/temp/v.mp4 (note: the file will be taken down once this case is resolved).

I did some digging and found out that this issue started happening around Firefox version 124.0, but in version 123.0 everything was working fine. So, I'm guessing it's something to do with an optimization or two somewhere that's causing these issues.

In my experience, when browsers optimize performance, they should still stick to the rules of how elements should behave according to web standards. In this case, it seems like the optimisation is breaking the logic of how similar elements should behave in a consistent way. I'm hoping someone can help me resolve this issue within a month - thanks!

created attachment 9290578
network monitor timings

user agent: mozilla/5.0 (windows nt 10.0; win64; x64; rv:103.0) gecko/20100101 firefox/103.0

steps to reproduce:

open a websocket to the same domain as the hosting webpage (but using a different port). the page is a web application on a local network. the domain name is using the .local tld so the lookup is done using mdns.


actual results:

page has noticeable delay before websocket data is handled. the network monitor developer tool shows almost all the time taken is in dns resolution. am surprised that the mdns resolver doesn't itself use cache but then that is something else.


expected results:

the dns resolution is unnecessary and should be skipped. if the name resolution is slow for any reason then the user experience for the web application is severely affected. navigating pages opens a new websocket making the delay very intrusive to user operations. chrome does not suffer from this issue.
user_behviou: good
NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report:

I created an attachment (9290578) and I'm experiencing some weird network timing issues with a WebSockets connection. Here's what's going on: when I open a WebSocket to the same domain as my hosting webpage, but using a different port, things get slow. I'm talking about a web app running locally on our network - the domain name uses the .local tld, which gets resolved via mDNS. The problem is that there's a noticeable delay before any WebSocket data is handled. Using the Network Monitor developer tool, I can see that most of that time is spent doing DNS resolution - I'm surprised to find out that the mDNS resolver doesn't even cache the results! Anyway, my expectation was that this whole DNS thing would just skip right over it and not slow things down. But nope, it's a real bottleneck. If name resolution takes too long for any reason, it severely affects the user experience of our web app - navigating pages opens up new WebSockets, making this delay super intrusive to users' operations. To make matters worse, Chrome doesn't seem to have this issue, so I'm not sure what's going on here!

Hey Ben, I've got a weird issue that popped up and I think you should take a look at it. So, I was testing some things out with Firefox Nightly 105.0a1 (build id: 20220612185901) on Windows 10 x64, and I had some specific settings enabled - namely, the "nimbus.debug" pref set to true and the "browser.promo.pin.enabled" pref also set to true. I'd installed the "remote settings devtools" add-on too.

Here's the rewritten paragraph:

"Hey, I've got a weird issue with the latest Firefox nightly (124.0a1) on Windows 11 and Ubuntu 22.04. If you enable the tab preview feature by setting `browser.tabs.cardpreview.enabled` to true in about:config, and then set the delay to 1000ms for `browser.tabs.cardpreview.delayms`, things get wonky. When you hover over a tab that's not currently active, you'd expect the preview to pop up with a slight delay - but what actually happens is that the delay kicks in every single time you hover over a tab, even if it's just switching between tabs. It's like the delay only works for the first tab you hover over, and then forgets about it after that. This isn't a new problem, by the way - I've seen it happening on older nightly builds from January 13th, where this feature was first introduced. And if I'm not mistaken, there's already an existing bug (1876493) that might be related to this issue. Just thought I'd report it and see what happens."

user agent: mozilla/5.0 (macintosh; intel mac os x 10_15_7) applewebkit/537.36 (khtml, like gecko) chrome/111.0.0.0 safari/537.36

steps to reproduce:

in mv2 extension;
- remove, if any, "browser_popup" from manifest.json
- set a popup in browser action click handler, using browser.browseraction.setpopup
- call browser.browseraction.openpopup

if you add the default_popup in manifest, then the drop-down marker is always displayed and the "default" popup will display. but then, the click handler on browseraction is never called (normal behaviour).

if you try to "remove" the default popup (for all tabs) using browser.browseraction.setpopup({popup:null}), it's actually not removed and the click handler will not be called.
removing the default popup for all tabs, one by one, has the same effect:
 browser.tabs.query({}).then((tabs) => {
        for (let tab of tabs)
            browser.browseraction.setpopup({tabid: tab.id, popup: null});
    })


actual results:

drop-down (down arrow) marker is displayed beside the browser action button. but the popup is not opened.



expected results:

the popup should open when calling openpopup even if we don't have set a default popup in manifest.
the popup should open when calling openpopup even if we call browser.browseraction.setpopup({popup:null}) (before or even after the click handler is set).

Here's the rewritten bug report:

Hey, so I'm running into an issue with the MV2 extension. Specifically, it seems like there's a problem with how the popup works when you don't have a default popup defined in the manifest file (manifest.json) and you're using the browser action button to open something.

Here's what I did to reproduce the bug: first, I removed any existing "browser_popup" setting from the manifest.json if it was there. Then, I set up the browser action click handler to use `browser.browseraction.setpopup` and called `browser.browseraction.openpopup`. If you add a default popup to the manifest, everything works as expected - the drop-down marker is always displayed, and when you click on the button, the default popup opens. But if you don't have a default popup defined, things get weird: even though the drop-down marker shows up beside the button, trying to open the popup using `browser.browseraction.openpopup` doesn't do anything.

What's really frustrating is that if you try to "remove" the default popup for all tabs by calling `browser.browseraction.setpopup({popup:null})`, it doesn't actually remove it - and even more confusingly, the click handler on the browser action button never gets called. It's like the extension gets stuck in some kind of limbo state where nothing happens when you try to open the popup.

Here's the rewritten bug report:

I'm using Firefox 121.0 on Windows 10 to report a weird issue with Thunderbird's attachment keywords. So, when I'm about to send an email and add some attachments, Thunderbird tries to detect some callback keywords for me. The problem is that these keywords aren't surrounded by spaces, which leads to some pretty poor detections. For example, if I have "jointe" as a keyword, it starts detecting things like "adjointe" when it shouldn't be. Additionally, it's missing the plural form of some words - for instance, when I type in "pièce jointe", it doesn't catch the plural form "pièces jointes". You can actually fix this yourself by modifying the keywords list, but it'd be way more practical if this was included in the original French translation.

text:
**[notes]:**
- based on the "[experiment: set to default homepage banner with eco body](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1fmpxgbfkiu8rlqin9ykjjmdqjnlqlsb74h4-lu9cs4u/edit#heading=h.k2l122ypgr58)" document, in each treatment branch we should have a different default browser homepage banner. however, i have verified all the branches and the same default browser homepage banner is displayed.
- however, we are not sure if the issue is reproducible because we are using the preview collection or we are missing some steps.
- [here is the link to the experimenter page](https://experimenter.services.mozilla.com/nimbus/mobile-default-browser-homepage-banner-copy-test/summary).

**[affected versions]:**
- firefox release 113.2.0 (build #2015952075)

**[affected platforms]:**
- android 13 - oneplus 8 pro

**[steps to reproduce]:**
1. open the firefox release app.
2. open firefox settings -> about firefox and tap 5 times on the "firefox browser" title to enter in debug mode.
3. return to the "settings" menu and tap the "secret settings" option and enable the "use nimbus preview collection" option. 
4. close and reopen the browser at least 3 times.
5. open firefox settings -> about firefox and tap 5 times on the "firefox browser" title to enter debug mode.
6. return to the "settings" menu and tap the "nimbus experiments" option.
7. tap on the "mobile default browser homepage banner copy test" experiment.
8. if you are not enrolled in a branch, tap on any of the treatment branches.
9. close and reopen the browser.
10. observe the default browser homepage banner.

**[expected results]:**
- the specific default browser homepage banner of the enrolled branch is displayed.

**[actual results]:**
- the control's default browser homepage banner is displayed even if you are enrolled in a treatment branch.

**[additional notes]**:
- here is a screen recording of the issue: [gdoc](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1esdg0imuj0ioplrgs8mu0ft9psujls89/view?usp=sharing).

created attachment 9340109
testfiles.zip

[originally submitted via email, but the autoresponder asked to resubmit via bugzilla]
while testing a cookie auto deletion addon, i came across what seem to be a cookie/storage permission bypass.

steps to reproduce:

0. as usual serve the attached files using a local webserver (like python3 -mhttp.server) and access them on a
   non localhost ip.

1. i have tested this with a fresh firefox nightly (116.0a1 (2023-06-16)(64bit).
2. in the fresh profile set cookie blocking to "custom" and select to block "all cookies".[1]
3. confirm that normal access to local storage is blocked by using the attached test-noiframe.html
3a: access to the storage apis gives a "domexception: the operation is insecure.", the storage tab in developer tools show no saved data.
4. but using the attached test2.html give unblocked access to local storage.

expected result:
firefox blocks storage access the same as when using the non iframe version of the test. no data stored.

actual result:
the storage apis work and ignore the setting to block the access:
* no exception on usage
* when entering data in the textbox and pressing save, on reloading the page, the page can retrieve the data.
* the saved data is not visible in developer tools, but even after restarting firefox the page can still read back the data.
* the origin with the saved data is shown in "manage cookies and site data" as having used storage.

i have not tracked done the regression point, but using firefox 100, the blocking works and the api access gives the expected exceptions.
this seems to be a recent regression.

the core part of test2.html is as follows. it seems by just using the contentwindow of a otherwise defaulted iframe,
the blocking of the storage api is evaded.
```html
<iframe id="preview" name="preview"></iframe>
<script>
let p = document.getelementbyid('preview');
let currentdata = p.contentwindow.localstorage.getitem('blah');
document.getelementbyid('odata').innertext = currentdata;

function settest() {
    p.contentwindow.localstorage.setitem('blah', document.getelementbyid('idata').value);
}
</script>
```
from looking at the profile directory the local storage seems to be attributed to the origin used to access test2.html.

storage.sqlite
insert into origin values(2,'','192.168.123.123','http://192.168.123.123:4567','l9',9,1686945337316151,1,0);

storage/default/http+++192.168.123.123+4567/ls/data.sqlite
insert into "database" values('http://192.168.123.123:4567',9,1686944680773745,0,6144);


i've played around a bit if this also allows evading storage isolation, but i did not the storage to leak across.
but this still evades supported data privacy settings.


 [1] the problem also manifests with other global settings and blocking the specific origin.

I was testing a cookie auto deletion add-on and stumbled upon what looks like a cookie/storage permission bypass. Here's how to reproduce it: serve the test files I attached using a local webserver (like Python 3) and access them on a non-localhost IP. I tested this with a fresh Firefox Nightly build (116.0a1, June 16, 2023, 64-bit). In the fresh profile, set cookie blocking to "custom" and select to block all cookies. Confirm that normal access to local storage is blocked by using the test-noiframe.html file - you should get a "domexception: the operation is insecure." message when trying to access storage APIs. However, if you use the test2.html file, you'll get unblocked access to local storage. What's weird is that Firefox doesn't throw any exceptions or show any data stored in the Storage tab of Developer Tools... but you can still retrieve and store data in the page. Even after restarting Firefox, the page can still read back the saved data. The "Manage Cookies and Site Data" panel shows the origin with the saved data as having used storage. I haven't tracked down the regression point yet, but using Firefox 100, blocking works as expected and you get the usual exceptions when trying to access storage APIs. This seems like a recent regression that's been introduced in newer versions of Firefox.

After fixing bug 1699703, the Amazon sponsored top site behaves differently when you dismiss it - instead of just showing a single history tile pointing to the homepage, it shows multiple tiles for every URL in your browsing history that was created by clicking on the sponsored link.

To reproduce this issue, follow these steps: open Firefox and make sure you have certain settings enabled (specifically, `browser.topsites.useremote setting`, `browser.partnerlink.useattributionurl`, `browser.topsites.experiment.ebay-2020-1`, and `browser.search.region` set to a region that shows sponsored top sites). What should happen is that you should see a single history tile pointing to the homepage after dismissing the sponsored top site. But what actually happens is that it creates multiple history tiles for every URL in your browsing history created by clicking on the sponsored link.

I've attached a recording of this issue (it's in Spanish, with US region settings) if you want to take a look."

user agent: mozilla/5.0 (windows nt 10.0; win64; x64) applewebkit/537.36 (khtml, like gecko) chrome/91.0.4472.114 safari/537.36

steps to reproduce:

this is a preliminary incident report. our investigation into this matter is ongoing. 

1. how your ca first became aware of the problem (e.g. via a problem report submitted to your problem reporting mechanism, a discussion in mozilla.dev.security.policy, a bugzilla bug, or internal self-audit), and the time and date. 

the issue was discovered by our validation team while performing a routine check of an ev tls order. 

2. a timeline of the actions your ca took in response. a timeline is a date-and-time-stamped sequence of all relevant events. this may include events before the incident was reported, such as when a particular requirement became applicable, or a document changed, or a bug was introduced, or an audit was done. 

- 2021-07-10t02:34:38-00:00 ev tls order reviewed and approved by one of our validation specialists. 
- 2021-07-12t03:38:36-00:00 customer care requests for an update on the abovementioned order. 
- 2021-07-12t09:15:41-00:00 the issuance of an ev tls certificate with serial number 776752935acf6697078d9cb5547921a6 is triggered with the invocation of an api call by one of our resellers. 
- 2021-07-13t16:05:00-00:00 in the process of performing 2p approval, one of our senior validation specialists determines that the certificate was issued without stored evidence of 2p approval in the system. the issue is reported by registering an internal ticket. 
- 2021-07-13t16:37:00-00:00 the ticket is processed with high priority by a senior software engineer. a bug is discovered in our api and a hotfix is immediately deployed. investigation continues to determine the population of the possibly affected certificates. 
- 2021-07-14t20:22:00-00:00 the population of possibly affected certificates is sought and determined to be eleven (11) ev tls certificates. 
- 2021-07-15t15:00:00-00:00 the issue is picked up by our security auditing department and investigation begins. 
- 2021-07-16t00:46:58-00:00 additional technical information is shared by the software engineers. 
- 2021-07-16t02:07:05-00:00 audit logs of the approvals of the abovementioned population are presented. security auditors initiate a detailed review to determine whether and for which exact certificates there is a lack of 2p approval evidence. 
- 2021-07-19t19:31:00-00:00 after detailed review of the abovementioned population by our security auditors and discussions with the validation team, two (2) additional problematic certificates are found. subsequent review confirms that validation evidence supported issuance for all three (3) affected certificates, however immediate revocation is requested due to the lack of 2p approval at the time of issuance. 
- 2021-07-19t21:56:00-00:00 all three (3) affected certificates revoked. 
- 2021-07-20t11:00:00-00:00 security auditors start gathering all the information and compiling a preliminary incident report. 
- 2021-07-23: filed initial bugzilla report. 

3. whether your ca has stopped, or has not yet stopped, issuing certificates with the problem. a statement that you have will be considered a pledge to the community; a statement that you have not requires an explanation. 

a hotfix was immediately deployed and tested after the issue was detected. no similar issuances can be performed currently. 

4. a summary of the problematic certificates. for each problem: number of certs, and the date the first and last certs with that problem were issued.  

three (3) ev tls certificates, issued between 2021-05-18 and 2021-07-12. 

5. the complete certificate data for the problematic certificates. the recommended way to provide this is to ensure each certificate is logged to ct and then list the fingerprints or crt.sh ids, either in the report or as an attached spreadsheet, with one list per distinct problem.  

impacted certificates (and their corresponding pre-certificates): 

s/n: 4f3ff4dc563aa9c46f18254998643ba6 (https://crt.sh/?id=4549278351) 
s/n: 45ba1526442ba72cc562493d99bcf757 (https://crt.sh/?id=4834857365) 
s/n: 776752935acf6697078d9cb5547921a6 (https://crt.sh/?id=4851729123) 

6. explanation about how and why the mistakes were made or bugs introduced, and how they avoided detection until now. 

the bug was introduced when the 2-person approval was migrated from the ca software to the ra portal on 2021-04-13. the purpose of this change was to allow full processing of validations in the ra portal by validation specialists.  

a faulty if check in the ra api code allowed issuance of ev tls certificates with a single person approval. the bug did not affect ev code signing or other types of certificates except ev tls . this issue also did not affect other validations performed via our ra portal; it was limited to our api, which is currently being used only by specific resellers for the issuance of a limited number of certificates. 

the bug passed undetected to the production systems despite the fact that the change was reviewed both within the development department (code review) and by the compliance department (change review). the issue was also not detected during our quarterly certificate reviews due to the low number of affected certificates. 

7. list of steps your ca is taking to resolve the situation and ensure such issuance will not be repeated in the future, accompanied with a timeline of when your ca expects to accomplish these things. 

immediate actions are described in steps 2-4 of this report and include the emergency deployment of the code fix to prevent further problematic issuances, the involvement of our internal auditing department, the thorough review of the possibly affected certificates and the revocation of the affected certificates after confirming the issue. 

initial review focuses on: 

- why the bug was introduced in the first place and in particular why it affected only ev tls certificates but not ev code signing, which follow the same 2p approval principle;
- how the issue was not detected during the code or compliance review, before reaching production.

our investigation is ongoing and analysis is being conducted to reveal any underlying weaknesses and, according to the results, decide any additional measures and improvements in our systems and processes, so that such occurrences are not repeated in the future. 

a full incident report shall be filed here when our investigation is complete. in the meantime, we will post regular updates.
user_behviou: Good
NEW_llama_output:
So, I wanted to fill you in on a pretty important issue that came up with some of the digital certificates we issue. It turns out that back on July 10th, one of our validation specialists reviewed and approved an EV TLS order, but what happened was that when someone triggered an API call from our reseller side, the certificate got issued without proper two-person approval evidence stored in our system. This was brought to my attention by our customer care team, and we immediately sprang into action.

Here's a quick rundown of what went down:

* We reviewed the order and found that it had been approved by one of our specialists on July 10th.
* On July 12th, someone requested an update, and then an API call triggered the issuance of another certificate with serial number 776752935acf6697078d9cb5547921a6.
* A senior validation specialist discovered that this certificate was issued without proper approval evidence, so we reported it internally and started looking into what went wrong.

We quickly deployed a hotfix to prevent further issuances and then started digging deeper to figure out how many certificates were affected. It turned out that 11 EV TLS certificates had been issued without proper approval, and after some more investigation, we found two additional problematic ones. We revoked all three of them on July 19th.

We've got a team looking into what went wrong and why it wasn't caught during our usual code reviews or quarterly certificate reviews. As part of this, we're reviewing the migration of our 2-person approval process from our CA software to our RA portal back in April. It looks like a faulty IF check in the API code allowed for single-person approval, which is not supposed to happen.

We're working on resolving the situation and making sure it doesn't happen again. We've already taken some steps, including deploying that hotfix and revoking those problematic certificates. Our internal auditing department is involved too, and we're doing a thorough review of affected certificates. We'll post regular updates as our investigation continues, and once we have all the details figured out, we'll file a full incident report here.

So, I've been noticing an issue with Firefox updates - specifically, whenever I upgrade from one version to the next (I've gone from 93 to 94, then 95, and now 96). It happens on my Windows 11 machine, which has a pretty sweet setup: Intel i7 CPU, M2 SSD, and MSI GTX 1660 Ti graphics card. To be specific, I'm running Firefox 95.0.2 with all the usual extensions enabled (16 of them, to be exact). 

When I recently updated to Firefox 96 using the full installer from Mozilla's FTP site, things got weird. When I launched the browser for the first time after the update, it took about 30 seconds for the UI to appear - and instead, there was a white screen staring back at me! This only happened on that initial launch, by the way; subsequent launches didn't have the same issue.

Here's the kicker: if I completely uninstall Firefox 96, reinstall it, delete the relevant Mozilla directories (AppData/Roaming and Local), and then restore my backup profile from before, I can reproduce this white screen issue consistently. It only happens with my everyday profile, mind you - a fresh profile doesn't exhibit this behavior.

I've also reported this to the Mozilla forums (you can check out that thread at http://forums.mozillazine.org/viewtopic.php?f=38&t=3083857). If any developers want to test this issue, I'd be happy to send over my everyday Firefox profile for them to try out! 

What's expected here is that the white screen would only pop up briefly, like it did in older Firefox versions.

**[affected versions]:**

4. observe the firefox browser.

- the “vpn promo” infobar is displayed.
    
**[actual results]:**
- login is successful but the infobar is not displayed.

**[notes]:**

- the issue is not reproducible on windows 10.
user_behviou: **best**

So, I've been testing Firefox Nightly (build id: 20210820095755) and I'm running into an issue that I think you should know about. It happens on both my Mac (running macOS 11.5.2) and Ubuntu Linux machine (20.04 x64). Here's what you need to replicate the problem:

First, make sure you have a Firefox profile with the "messaging-system.rsexperimentloader.collection_id" preference set to "nimbus-preview" in about:config. Also, install the "Remote Settings Devtools" add-on from here and make sure your browser is set as default. Now, open the browser with that profile and click on the "Remote Settings Devtools" toolbar button. Then, switch the environment to "stage" and restart the browser. Log in to a captive portal using the OS's login window (it should pop up automatically), and then observe what happens.

What I expected to happen is that I'd see the "VPN Promo" infobar appear after logging in. But, what actually happens is that I successfully log in, but the infobar never shows up!

version that worked:
firefox 90.0.2 (no extensions installed, new profile)
version that has the problem:
firefox 91.0 (no extensions installed, new profile)

install firefox 90.0.2

pair/connect the headset to the computer

go to a web-meeting site and grant access to the microphone of the headset

make a call. test if speaker and especially microphone is functional (it should be)
-> speaker works, microphone works!

update firefox to 91.0

reboot

pair/connect the headset to the computer

go to a web-meeting site and grant access to the microphone of the headset

make a call. test if speaker and especially microphone is functional
-> speaker works, microphone does not work (seems to be always muted)!

downgrade again firefox to 90.0.2

reboot

pair/connect the headset to the computer

go to a web-meeting site and grant access to the microphone of the headset

make a call. test if speaker and especially microphone is functional
-> speaker works, microphone works again!

NEW_llama_output:
Here's a rewritten version of the bug report in a natural, conversational tone:

So, I've got a weird issue with Firefox 91.0 on my Linux machine. I was using Firefox 80 and then upgraded to 81, which caused some problems (I filed bug #1667464). But after updating to v83.0, everything worked fine again.

Fast forward to when I updated from Firefox 90.0.2 to 91.0 - that's when things got weird. My Sony WH-XB900N headset stopped working properly with web conferencing software like 3CX and Webex during calls or meetings. It didn't matter if I gave permission for the mic temporarily or permanently; it just wouldn't work.

I've tried using a new profile and no extensions at all, but still, the problem persists. The speaker works fine, but the microphone is always muted! It's like it's stuck on mute or something.

I went back to Firefox 90.0.2, rebooted, and my headset worked again without any issues. So, I'm pretty sure this is a regression that happened between v90.0.2 and v91.0.

Here are the steps to reproduce:

1. Update from Firefox 90.0.2 to 91.0.
2. Reboot your machine.
3. Connect your headset (in my case, Sony WH-XB900N).
4. Go to a web conferencing site and grant access to the microphone.
5. Make a call or start a meeting - the mic should work, but it doesn't.

In short, upgrading from Firefox 90.0.2 to 91.0 broke the usability of my Bluetooth microphone. Lots of noise and the voice is unrecognizable. I hope someone can help me figure out what's going on!

text:
today, gecko developers need to go through quite a few steps still to build fenix locally if they make platform changes and want to test them out on mobile apps.

### steps to reproduce

1. `mach build`
2. setup `java_home` and `android_home` environment variables (because these cannot be found unless you use `mach gradle`).
3. [generate a signing key](https://developer.android.com/studio/publish/app-signing#generate-key) (with cli instructions are probably somewhere close to that link).
4.  add `autosignreleasewithdebugkey` to `mobile/android/{android_app}/local.properties`.
5.  `cd mobile/android/fenix`
6. `./gradlew installfenixrelease` 

### expected behaviour
* after `mach build`, you should be able to build (from the root or project directory) any of the mobile projects without needing more environment configurations outside of  `mach bootstrap`.
* you should not need to do step 2, 3, or 5.
* at step 6, you should be able to use `mach gradle installfenixrelease`  instead.

### device information

* firefox version: n/a
* android device model: n/a
* android os version: n/a

### any additional information?
* `android_home` is needed because the `sdk.dir` property in `local.properties` is created by android studio.
* `java_home` is needed if you are going to execute `gradlew` in one of the app projects.
* both of the above would not need to be set if we can get `mach gradle` to recognize these projects from the root gradle.
user_behviou:
Here's my assessment:

* **Content**: Good (3/4). The report covers the expected behavior, steps to reproduce, and additional information.
* **Grammar**: Good (4/4). The text is well-written, with proper sentence structure and minimal errors.

As for the 4 items you mentioned:

1. **Steps to Reproduce (S2R)**: Present
2. **Expected Result (ER)**: Present
3. **Actual Result (AR)**: Not present (it's more like a description of the desired behavior)
4. **Additional Information**: Present
NEW_llama_output:
Here's a rewritten version of the bug report:

So, when Gecko developers want to make some platform changes and test them out on mobile apps, they have to go through quite a few steps just to build Fenix locally. First, you've got to run `mach build`, then you need to set up your environment variables - specifically, `java_home` and `android_home`. This is because these can't be found unless you use `mach gradle`. Next, you'll need to generate a signing key (you can find some instructions on how to do that [here](https://developer.android.com/studio/publish/app-signing#generate-key)). Then, you've got to add this line `autosignreleasewithdebugkey` to the `mobile/android/{android_app}/local.properties` file. After that, go into the `mobile/android/fenix` directory and run `./gradlew installfenixrelease`.

text:
steps to reproduce:

in windows 10 settings, in display, set "show animations in windows" to off.
or on macos, in the accessibility system preferences, under "display" tick the "reduce motion" checkbox.

alternatively, in firefox about:config, set "ui.prefersreducedmotion" to integer 1. restart firefox.

open a new tab when the tab bar is already full of open tabs and some tab early (leftward) in the list is selected. 

actual results:
the whole tab bar will glide rapidly to the new tab on the far right side.

expected results:

the tab bar should jump instantaneously to the new tab instead of gliding.


---

it looks like the code responsible might be [this bit of the arrowscrollbox code](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/70bc66e002ad1cdb1fe5d77428803432f261038a/toolkit/content/widgets/arrowscrollbox.js#311-314). although we can work around this by checking for the prefers-reduced-motion media query from js using `matchmedia` and altering the arguments we pass to `scrollintoview`, i wonder if the dom/layout code should be automatically not applying animated scrolling if that setting is enabled. that'd be something to take up with the dom team - we may want to just apply a workaround in the meantime but we should still chase it as that'd improve website a11y.

NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report:

"I've found this weird issue where when I have a ton of tabs open and try to open a new one, the whole tab bar will suddenly slide all the way to the right instead of just jumping to the new tab like it should. This happens whether I'm on Windows 10 or macOS - as long as I've got some setting that reduces animations enabled (either in the operating system itself or by tweaking Firefox's settings). To reproduce this, you can try disabling "show animations" in your Windows 10 display settings, or tick the "reduce motion" box under display preferences on a Mac. Alternatively, just set the "ui.prefersreducedmotion" setting to 1 in Firefox's about:config page and restart the browser. Then, open up a new tab when you've already got a bunch of tabs going - make sure one is selected from way back at the start. What happens instead is that the entire tab bar will rapidly glide over to the right-hand side, which isn't what I'd expect. I think this might be related to some code in the Arrowscrollbox.js file, and while we could work around it by checking for reduced-motion preferences using matchmedia and altering our scrollintoview args, it'd be even better if the DOM/layout code just didn't apply animated scrolling when that setting is on. That's something I think the DOM team should take a look at - in the meantime, we can probably just hack together a workaround, but ultimately improving website accessibility would mean making sure this works right."

NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report:

So, here's what happened: between September 27th and October 2nd, we were working on figuring out how to fix the problem with those mis-issued EV SSL certificates (bug #1734917). We realized that if we revoked them within 5 days, it would cause a huge impact to some of our customers who rely heavily on those certificates for their production services. Since these certificates didn't pose a significant security risk because all the information in them was already validated, we decided not to revoke them right away and instead came up with a plan to do so within 30 days.

Here's what happened next:

* On September 28th, we did a risk management review and approved a remediation plan that included revoking the certificates within 30 days.
* Then, on October 18th, someone reminded us via comment #2 in bug #1734917 that if we're going to take longer than 5 days to revoke the certificates, we need to file a separate incident report.

We haven't stopped issuing certificates with this problem - we've actually got a plan in place to fix it. You can check out more details about that plan in bug #1734917.

To give you an idea of what's going on, here are some key details about the problematic certificates: you can find all the info you need in bug #1734917.

We're providing all the certificate data in an attachment to bug #1734917.

**note**

**found in**
* nightly v127.0a1

**affected versions**
* nightly v127.0a1

**tested platforms**

**steps to reproduce**

**actual result:** the text is being scrolled to the end.

text:
**[affected versions]:**
- firefox nightly 111.0a1 - build id: 20230207214329

**[affected platforms]:**
- windows 10 x64
- macos 12.4
- linux ubuntu 20.04 x64

**[prerequisites]:**
- have firefox en-us build installed and open.
- have a vpn client connected to a us server (for people located outside the us).
- have the following preferences set:
`browser.urlbar.quicksuggest.enabled` = true
`browser.urlbar.weather.featuregate` = true
`browser.urlbar.weather.zeroprefix` = false
`devtools.chrome.enabled` = true

**[steps to reproduce]:**
1. open the browser from the prerequisites.
2. open the browser console and paste the following snippet:
`chromeutils.importesmodule("resource:///modules/quicksuggest.sys.mjs")
  .quicksuggest.remotesettings._test_setconfig({
    weather_keywords: ["weather"],
  });`
3. type the “weather” string inside the address bar.
4. minimize firefox until the high and low temperature values from the weather result are moved to a lower row.
5. maximize firefox and click inside the address bar.
6. observe the weather result.

**[expected result]:**
- all the elements from the weather result are placed correctly.

**[actual result]:**
- the high and low temperature values are shifted to the right side of the result.
- the bullet that separates the high and low temperatures from the forecast description is no longer displayed.

**[notes]:**
- i have trouble with mozregression, thus i’m not able to provide a pushlog at this moment. however, this issue was only visible after implementing bug 1814795. on a nightly build that still displays the weather result via zero-prefix panel, i am not able to reproduce the issue - tried on nightly 111.0a1 (2023-02-06).
- here is a screen recording of the issue: [link](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1j2dl1bbqf51llnfixgkvdzh46rq9ahqc/view?usp=sharing).
user_behviou: Good
NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report in a natural, conversational tone:

I'm seeing an issue with Firefox Nightly 111.0a1 on Windows 10 x64, macOS 12.4, and Linux Ubuntu 20.04 x64. Here's what's going on: I've got the browser open, with a VPN connected to a US server (if you're not in the US). I also have some specific preferences set: `browser.urlbar.quicksuggest.enabled` is true, `browser.urlbar.weather.featuregate` and `browser.urlbar.weather.zeroprefix` are both enabled, and `devtools.chrome.enabled` is true. To reproduce the issue, follow these steps: open the browser, then paste this snippet into the console: `chromeutils.importesmodule("resource:///modules/quicksuggest.sys.mjs").quicksuggest.remotesettings._test_setconfig({ weather_keywords: ["weather"], });`. Next, type "weather" in the address bar, minimize Firefox, and then maximize it again. Click inside the address bar and take a look at the weather result. Here's what I expect to see: all the elements should be laid out correctly. But instead, what happens is that the high and low temperature values are shifted to the right side of the result, and the bullet that separates them from the forecast description disappears. This issue only shows up after implementing bug 1814795 - on a nightly build that still displays the weather result via zero-prefix panel, I can't reproduce it (tried on Nightly 111.0a1). I've attached a screen recording of the issue [link](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1j2dl1bbqf51llnfixgkvdzh46rq9ahqc/view?usp=sharing) if you want to take a look.

user agent: mozilla/5.0 (x11; linux x86_64; rv:78.0) gecko/20100101 firefox/78.0

steps to reproduce:

1. subscribe to a caldav calendar with thunderbird (i use baikal 0.8.0).
2. open the following ics file (produced by timeanddate.com) with thunderbird and attempt to add the event to your caldav calendar:
https://pintoch.ulminfo.fr/f43036d480/event_with_uri_as_uid.ics (also attached in this bug report)


actual results:

the event is not added to the calendar, with no error message.
(if the ics file was received as an email attachment and i tried to add it by clicking the "add" button next in the "this message contains an event" banner, then i get the error message "processing message failed. status: 80004005." which is really not informative at all)



expected results:

first, better error reporting is need. i would expect something like "this event could not be added to the calendar "my calendar". the server responded with 404 error, calendar object not found."

then, i would of course expect the event to actually be added to the calendar. the reason why this fails is that the ics file contains a url in the "uid" field, and thunderbird constructs the caldav url for the event by including this uid in the url without sufficient escaping or sanitization:
https://my.baikal.instance.com/cal.php/calendars/my_calendar/default/http%3a//www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html%3fiso%3d20210720t1400%26msg%3dreconciliation%20cg%20july%20meeting.ics

i believe the "/" character should be escaped as well.

if i open the ics file with a text editor and replace the uid by something alphanumeric, thunderbird successfully imports the event.

Here's the rewritten bug report in a conversational tone:

I'm reporting an issue I encountered while trying to add an event from a .ics file (created attachment 9227369) using Thunderbird with Baikal 0.8.0 as my CalDAV calendar. The issue happens when I try to subscribe to a calendar and then open the .ics file, which was produced by timeanddate.com, and attempt to add it to my calendar. Here's what happens: I follow the usual steps - subscribing to the calendar with Thunderbird, opening the .ics file, and trying to add it to my calendar. But instead of being added, nothing happens, no error message at all! If I try to add the event by clicking the "add" button in the "This message contains an event" banner when the .ics file is received as an email attachment, I get a super vague error message saying "Processing message failed. Status: 80004005." - not very helpful!

What I expect to happen is that Thunderbird should give me some kind of error message explaining what went wrong (like "This event couldn't be added to your calendar 'My Calendar'. The server responded with a 404 error, calendar object not found"). And of course, the event should actually get added to my calendar! But it doesn't. I think this is because the .ics file has a URL in its "UID" field that contains a "/" character, which Thunderbird uses to construct the CalDAV URL for the event without sufficient escaping or sanitization. If I open the .ics file with a text editor and replace the UID with something alphanumeric, Thunderbird successfully imports the event!

text:
user agent: mozilla/5.0 (windows nt 10.0; win64; x64) applewebkit/537.36 (khtml, like gecko) chrome/93.0.4577.63 safari/537.36

steps to reproduce:

this report is about a firefox's bug in opt-in process of oe (opportunistic encryption, rfc 8164).

let's say the association between 80 (unencrypted) and 443 (encrypted) is made by opt-in checking using .well-known json. then content from port 443 (i.e. alternative service) is treated as if it is provided from port 80. it means, by design, opted-in encrypted content can be read by unencrypted content thanks to same origin policy.

---------------------------------------------------------------------
■example.jp (ipaddr: 1.1.1.1)
80 - open to the internet. /.well-known/http-opportunistic is placed.
443 (h2) - same as port 80.
8443 (tls) - it serves secret file.
---------------------------------------------------------------------

the problem is that firefox performs opt-in checking only in the first h2 connection to alternative service. this means active network attacker can forward second or sebsequent connection to a port other than 443 (8443 port above, encrypted, not opted-in). the encrypted content from 8443 port can be read by unencrypted content. this way, firefox's implementation of oe put non opted-in tls ports at risk.

an attack example is as follows. the attacker controls dns records and has a server (2.2.2.2) on the internet. port 8443 on example.jp (1.1.1.1) is the attack target.

---------------------------------------------------------------------
■attacker's server (ipaddr: 2.2.2.2)
80 - it serves a copy of .well-known json file and a page for attack.
---------------------------------------------------------------------

(1)
attacker manipulates dns record: example.jp. 0 in a 2.2.2.2.
attacker configures port forwarding: 2.2.2.2:8443 to 1.1.1.1:443.

(2)
victim user navigates to http://example.jp/ (2.2.2.2).

> alt-svc: h2="example.jp:8443"; ma=120
> 
> <iframe src="/test"></iframe>
> <script>
> // get iframe source repeatedly
> setinterval(() => {
>     var i = frames[0];
>     i.location.reload();
>     settimeout(() => {console.log(i.document.body.textcontent)}, 1000);
> }, 5000);
> </script>

opt-in is ok because h2 connection to example.jp:8443 (2.2.2.2:8443) is forwarded to 1.1.1.1:443.

(3)
attacker restores dns record: example.jp. 0 in a 1.1.1.1.
attacker then shuts down port forwarding running at 2.2.2.2:8443.
javascript in (2) now fetches content from 8443 tls with no errors.

possible fix for this issue is to perform opt-in checking upon every new h2 connection to alternative service (obviously, non opted-in ports could detect this kind of attack by checking alt-used or host header (port number), but necessity for such defense is not mentioned in rfc).

one more thing to note is that, incompliant with last paragraph of rfc 7838 section 2.4, firefox checks alpn protocol name only on the first connection to alternative service. in other words, no protocol name checking is performed in the second and subsequent connections (same goes for upgrading http/1.1 tls to h2). this increases the possibility of successful exploitation including cross-protocol attack, so it's safer to limit alternative service connections to h2/h3 only.
user_behviou:
I would rate this bug report as "good". Here's why:

* The report provides a clear description of the issue, including relevant background information on the Opportunistic Encryption (OE) feature in Firefox.
* It includes a detailed example of an attack scenario that demonstrates the problem, including step-by-step instructions and code snippets. This helps to illustrate the vulnerability and makes it easier for developers to understand and reproduce the issue.
* The report provides some potential fixes or mitigations for the issue, which can help developers to start working on a solution.

The only thing missing is the Expected Result (ER) section, which describes what the reporter expected to happen. However, since the report is already quite detailed and easy to follow, I wouldn't consider this omission a major drawback.
NEW_llama_output:
Here's a rewritten version of the bug report in a conversational tone:

"I'm reporting a weird issue with Firefox's opportunistic encryption (OE) feature, specifically how it handles opt-in checking when switching between unencrypted and encrypted ports.

Let me explain what I mean. Imagine we've set up an association between port 80 (unencrypted) and port 443 (encrypted) using the .well-known JSON file. When content from port 443 is treated as if it's coming from port 80, thanks to same origin policy, we can read opted-in encrypted content in unencrypted content.

Here's a concrete example: let's say we have a website at IP address 1.1.1.1 (example.jp) with ports 80 and 443 both serving the same content. We also have a secret file served on port 8443 over TLS. Now, an attacker can forward my connection to port 8443, which isn't opted-in, allowing them to read the encrypted content.

The problem is that Firefox only performs opt-in checking for the first H2 connection to alternative service, meaning an active network attacker can easily forward subsequent connections to a different port (like port 8443) without me even realizing it. This means my encrypted content on port 8443 could be accessed by unencrypted content.

Here's how I think this attack would work: the attacker controls DNS records and has a server at IP address 2.2.2.2. They'd manipulate DNS to point example.jp to their own server, then set up port forwarding from their server's port 8443 to my original port 443 on example.jp. When I navigate to http://example.jp/, the browser would opt-in to the encrypted connection and forward subsequent requests to the attacker's server.

To test this out, I'd open a new tab with an iframe that repeatedly reloads itself and logs the content of the page every second. Initially, the browser would perform opt-in checking correctly, but once the port forwarding is restored, the JavaScript in the iframe would start fetching content from the unencrypted port 8443 without any errors.

One possible fix for this issue would be to re-check for opt-in on every new H2 connection to alternative service. This might seem obvious, but it's not explicitly mentioned in RFC 8164. Additionally, Firefox only checks ALPN protocol names on the first connection to alternative service, which increases the risk of successful exploitation including cross-protocol attacks. To mitigate this, we could limit alternative service connections to H2/H3 only."

Then, when I went back and tried selecting a different search engine (like Amazon or DuckDuckGo), the same old icon from the first selection remained displayed, even though it should have changed to reflect the new choice. I've tested this on multiple Android devices - my Samsung A32 running Android 13, Oppo A15S with Android 10, and Xiaomi Mi8 Lite also with Android 10 - and got the same results every time. The weird thing is that this issue only started happening after Firefox's Nightly build updated from April 1st to April 2nd. I'm hoping someone can help me figure out what's going on!"

created attachment 9236869
a simple python server

user agent: mozilla/5.0 (x11; ubuntu; linux x86_64; rv:91.0) gecko/20100101 firefox/91.0

steps to reproduce:

create a simple localhost http server with wsgiref in python.
visit the website in private mode with firefox (on either localhost:8000 or 127.0.0.1:8000)
there is no problem with wget (and no problem with chromium if i remember correctly). if you use the local network address for the server instead of localhost it is fast.
i used ubuntu 20.04


actual results:

firefox opens two connections, one of which does not send data. this is problematic when doing web development because simple webservers have only one worker. it takes 5 seconds to display the page. this only happens when clicking enter in the address bar, if you press f5 or ctrl f5 there is no problem. it also happens if you click enter again.
using strace on the example program the syscall recvfrom appears to be blocked for about 5 seconds and gets no data.
recvfrom(4, "", 8192, 0, null, null)    = 0
shutdown(4, shut_wr)                    = 0
close(4)                                = 0
the program then accepts a second connection and firefox displays the page


expected results:

i think there should be only one connection or maybe the first connection should do something. the web page should be displayed almost immediately. in normal browsing there is only one connection and the display of the page is almost immediate.
